item.title: Fed’s Powell Says Tariff-Driven Inflation Remains a Big Question
item.description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell on Wednesday said the US central bank is still struggling to determine the impact of tariffs on consumer prices.
item.dc:creator: Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell testifies before a Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs hearing in Washington, on June 25.

item.title: Czechs See Little Room for Rate Cuts as Inflation Risks Increase
item.description: The Czech central bank signaled that interest rates will remain on hold at least for several months, saying inflationary risks prevented a cut in borrowing costs at a meeting on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca, Krystof Chamonikolas

media:content.media:description: The Czech central bank in Prague. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

item.title: Powell Says End of Fed’s Interest Paid to Banks Won’t Save Money
item.description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said a proposal to eliminate the interest paid to banks that deposit cash at the central bank would not save money, and moving back to a scarce reserves regime would be challenging and risk volatility.
item.dc:creator: Alex Harris

media:content.media:description: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell testifies before the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs during a hearing in Washington, DC, on June 25.

item.title: Fed’s Collins Favors ‘Actively Patient’ Approach to Rates
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Boston President Susan Collins said an “actively patient” approach to monetary policy is appropriate while assessing the impact of tariffs on the economy.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: President and CEO of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston Susan Collins

item.title: Ghana Plans First Sale of Domestic Bonds Since Debt Default
item.description: Ghana will resume domestic bond sales later in 2025 after short-term borrowing costs fell to the lowest levels in three years amid signs the nation is recovering from a recent debt crisis.
item.dc:creator: Ekow Dontoh

item.title: Trump Says Three or Four People on List to Replace Fed’s Powell
item.description: President Donald Trump said he has three or four people in mind to succeed Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell when his term expires next year.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC.

item.title: US New-Home Sales Drop by Most Since 2022 on Poor Affordability
item.description: US purchases of new homes fell in May by the most in almost three years as rampant sales incentives fell short of alleviating affordability constraints.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

media:content.media:description: Newly built homes in Loudonville, New York.

item.title: South Africans Feel the Pinch as Take-Home Pay Drops Again
item.description: South Africans real take-home pay declined by 1.1% in May from the previous month, according to BankservAfrica.
item.dc:creator: Zinhle Xaba

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians at the Victoria & Alfred Waterfront neighborhood in Cape Town, South Africa, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. South Africa’s ruling coalition risks unraveling after a dispute between its main members over proposed tax increases deepened, pummeling the rand.

item.title: Trump Administration Urges Appeals Court to Back Tariff Power
item.description: The Trump administration defended the president’s power to impose sweeping global tariffs, arguing to a federal appeals court that it should overturn a decision finding the levies unconstitutional.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: A container ship leaves the Port of Newark in Elizabeth, New Jersey.

item.title: Poland Floats New Bank Tax to Bolster Budget After Elections
item.description: Poland’s Finance Minister Andrzej Domanski unveiled a plan to introduce more taxes on lenders to bolster the country’s ailing budget.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski

media:content.media:description: Andrzej Domanski

item.title: Trump Policies Will Cut Deficits Up to $11 Trillion, White House Economist Says
item.description: President Donald Trump’s policies will reduce US fiscal deficits by up to $11 trillion over the coming decade, according to the White House’s chief economist — a projection that defies analysts who say government debt is poised to climb to record highs in coming years.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers Stephen Miran

item.title: US Firm Backs $760 Million Congo-Rwanda-Burundi Hydropower Plant
item.description: A long-delayed plan to build a hydropower plant on the Ruzizi River between Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo received a boost amid US-backed peace talks between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: Michael J Kavanagh

item.title: Swiss Are Still Holding Out for a US Trade Deal Before July 9
item.description: The Swiss government is still hoping to clinch a trade deal with the US before Donald Trump’s July 9 deadline, but otherwise expects tariffs to remain at the current 10% level if negotiations continue further.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright, Levin Stamm

media:content.media:description: Paradeplatz in Zurich. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

item.title: China Doesn’t Hold Upper Hand Versus US, Biden Official Says
item.description: It will take “a generation” to diversify some of the US dependency on China for rare earths and other segments of global supply chains, but that doesn’t mean Beijing holds the economic upper hand over Washington, former US Deputy Secretary of State Kurt Campbell said.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Haslinda Amin

media:content.media:description: Kurt Campbell

item.title: EU Sees Trump’s 10% Tariff as Trigger to Retaliate
item.description: The European Commission finally revealed how it’s planning to react to the likelihood of an additional 10% baseline tariff from the US on EU exports remaining in place.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero

item.title: China Building a ‘Mega-Sized’ Consumer Economy, Premier Says
item.description: Premier Li Qiang has projected confidence that China can turn consumption into a driver for the economy, while also portraying his nation as a stabilizing force in a rapidly shifting global trade landscape.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu, Linda Lew

item.title: Trump Eyes Little-Tested Tactic for Next Step in Spending Clash
item.description: President Donald Trump’s budget director is preparing to escalate the administration’s fight over federal spending with a little-tested tactic to claw back money in the last days of the fiscal year.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: Thailand Holds Key Rate, Raises Growth Outlook Despite Risks
item.description: The Bank of Thailand held its key interest rate unchanged after unexpectedly raising its growth forecast for 2025, with policymakers voting to preserve their firepower to deal with future risks ranging from US tariffs to the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana

item.title: Bipartisan Policy Center Sees Debt-Limit X-Date Soon as Aug. 15
item.description: A closely watched independent think tank has updated its estimate for when the federal government risks running out of sufficient funds to pay its obligations on time if Congress fails to suspend or lift the nation’s debt limit.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

item.title: China Makes Pitch for More Private Cash in Cross-Border Projects
item.description: China’s Finance Minister Lan Fo’an has urged a greater role for private investment in ensuring sustainable funding for cross-border infrastructure, warning that emerging countries are running short of money to spend on development.
item.dc:creator: Fran Wang

item.title: Switzerland Seeks Defense Cooperation With EU in New Talks
item.description: Switzerland wants to start exploratory talks on a defense partnership with the European Union as worries about a US retreat from the continent prompt a rethink of security policy in the traditionally neutral country.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Swiss soldiers.

item.title: EU Wants China to Fix Rare Earths Issue Before July Summit
item.description: The European Union wants China to resolve the export issue around rare earth magnets before a meeting of their leaders next month, according to the bloc’s top envoy to Beijing.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

media:content.media:description: Neodymium in Inner Mongolia. Photographer: Nelson Ching/

item.title: Japan Protests New Chinese Construction in East China Sea
item.description: China has stepped up construction of drilling rigs and other platforms off its east coast to tap into maritime resources such as natural gas and fish, raising the ire of Japan and South Korea and fanning fresh concerns about Beijing’s regional ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Sakura Murakami

item.title: Most Hawkish BOJ Member Flags Rate Hike Risk as Inflation Gains
item.description: The Bank of Japan’s most hawkish member said it may be necessary to raise interest rates should inflation risks rise even if economic uncertainty lingers.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

item.title: Indonesia’s Finance Chief Reassures Investors on Fiscal Discipline in Prabowo Era
item.description: Indonesia’s finance minister presented a unified front with President Prabowo Subianto, stressing that the government is committed to fiscal discipline while rolling out the new leader’s priority programs. Bonds extended a rally.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing, Prima Wirayani, Haslinda Amin

item.title: Australia’s Monthly CPI Cools, Cementing July Rate-Cut Case
item.description: A gauge of Australia’s monthly inflation cooled faster than anticipated in May, moving close to the bottom of the Reserve Bank’s 2-3% target and cementing the case for an interest-rate cut as soon as next month.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Bank of Thailand Insider, Top State Banker Vie for Governor Role
item.description: Thailand has shortlisted a career central banker and the head of a state-owned lender as finalists to lead the Bank of Thailand, an appointment closely watched by investors for insights into the future direction of monetary policy.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Thailand complex in Bangkok.

item.title: Czech Central Bank to Hold Rates and May Signal Longer Break
item.description: The Czech central bank will probably halt interest rate cuts again, with investors awaiting clues about the outlook that may signal a longer pause or even the end of monetary easing.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca

item.title: AIIB’s Outgoing President Stresses Openness to Global Partners
item.description: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank remains open to all countries, including the US and Japan, the lender’s outgoing president said, as the Beijing-based institution looks to emphasize its growing global reach.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Haslinda Amin

media:content.media:description: Jin Liqun, outgoing president of Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank.
